question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

RECEIVED

For the event concerning Elon Musk's attendance and statements at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, several factors must be considered to estimate the probabilities accurately.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: The probability of Musk attending the conference is likely influenced by his past involvement in similar events, his interest in Bitcoin, and any public commitments he has made. Given his significant influence in the cryptocurrency space, I would estimate this probability to be relatively high, around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is simply the complement of P, so it would be 1 - P, which would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is expected to be similar to P since it essentially asks the same question, so I would also estimate this at 0.65.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin during the conference)**: Given Musk's history of making statements about Bitcoin, especially during significant events, I would estimate this probability to be around 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This is the joint probability of both P and Q occurring. Given that these events are correlated (if Musk attends, he is more likely to make a statement), I would estimate this probability at around 0.50.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This probability should account for the likelihood of either event happening. It can be estimated using the formula: P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Thus, I would estimate this at 0.85.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not_P occurs)**: This is a bit tricky, as it requires Q to happen without P. Assuming that Musk could make a statement even if he doesn't attend, I would estimate this at around 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Given P, does Q occur?)**: This conditional probability should be quite high since if Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases significantly. I would estimate this at around 0.90.

In summary, the relationships between these events appear to be interdependent, particularly between P and Q. The estimates should also comply with the consistency rules to ensure that all derived probabilities align correctly.

Q_given_P: 0.90

or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.70) <= 0.85 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.70) is TRUE

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee and Mike Pence not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following occur: (a) Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (b) Mike Pence is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will either Mike Pence or Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Mike Pence or Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In evaluating the probability estimates for the questions regarding Elon Musk's potential appearance and statements at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, we need to consider the relationships between these events carefully.

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability will likely reflect a combination of Elon Musk's past behavior at similar events, the significance of Bitcoin in his public persona, and any announcements made leading up to the event.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is simply the complement of P, and thus should be calculated as 1 - P. The relationship between P and not_P is direct and governed by the negation rule.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is expected to be similar to P since both questions are fundamentally asking about his attendance. Therefore, it should have a similar probability to P.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability may be influenced by the context of the event and whether Musk has a vested interest in discussing Bitcoin at that time. It could be somewhat independent of P, as he might make a statement even if he does not attend.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This probability will depend on the relationship between P and Q. If both events are likely, this probability will be higher, but it will not exceed the individual probabilities of P and Q.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This probability will be higher than both individual probabilities and should follow the rules of addition of probabilities, ensuring it does not exceed 1.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q and not_P occur?)**: This is a more complex relationship as it requires that he makes a statement without attending. This could be plausible and should be calculated accordingly.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability will depend on the likelihood of him making a statement if he attends. It should be evaluated based on the context of the event and his past behavior.

In all cases, ensuring that the probabilities adhere to the consistency rules is crucial. For example, the relationship between P and not_P must hold true, as well as the relationships defined by the 'and', 'or', and 'conditional' rules. Each probability should be adjusted to maintain these relationships and ensure logical consistency.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee and Nikki Haley not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Nikki Haley is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It will resolve as **No** if either Donald Trump is not selected or Nikki Haley is selected. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are evaluating a series of questions related to Elon Musk's potential involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. Each question is binary, meaning it can resolve either positively (YES) or negatively (NO). 

1. **P**: This question asks whether Elon Musk will show up at the conference. Given his previous involvement in Bitcoin discussions and events, I estimate a moderate probability that he will attend, perhaps around **0.60**. 

2. **not_P**: This is the complementary question to P. If I estimate P at **0.60**, then not_P should logically be **0.40** (1 - P).

3. **para_P**: This question is similar to P and should have a similar probability since it essentially asks the same thing. Hence, I might also estimate para_P at **0.60**.

4. **Q**: This question asks whether Musk will make a public statement about Bitcoin during the conference. Given his history of discussing Bitcoin publicly, I estimate this probability at **0.70**.

5. **P_and_Q**: This question asks whether both P and Q will happen. To estimate this, I can use the formula for the intersection of two probabilities. Assuming P and Q are somewhat independent, I can estimate P_and_Q as **P * Q = 0.60 * 0.70 = 0.42**.

6. **P_or_Q**: This question asks whether either P or Q will happen. Using the formula for the union of two probabilities, I can estimate P_or_Q as **P + Q - P_and_Q = 0.60 + 0.70 - 0.42 = 0.88**.

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This question asks whether Q happens while P does not. Given the estimates, I can calculate this as **Q * not_P = 0.70 * 0.40 = 0.28**.

8. **Q_given_P**: This conditional question asks whether Q happens given that P has happened. Given that if Musk shows up, he's likely to make a statement, I might estimate this probability as higher than Q alone, perhaps around **0.85**.

Overall, I will ensure that all these estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided. For example, the relationship between P and not_P must hold true, and the intersections and unions must be calculated correctly to ensure they fall within the defined ranges. 

Additionally, I will ensure that the estimates reflect a realistic understanding of the events based on prior knowledge of Elon Musk's behavior and public statements.

question.title: Will either Nikki Haley or Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Nikki Haley or Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This event is significant as it directly relates to his attendance at a major Bitcoin conference. Given Musk's influence in the cryptocurrency space, I would estimate a moderate probability based on his past behavior at similar events.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is the complement of P. If I estimate P to be a certain value, not_P will be 1 minus that value. This relationship is straightforward and will help maintain consistency.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend)**: This should be closely aligned with P, as both essentially ask the same question. I would expect these probabilities to be equal or very close.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin during the conference)**: This event is independent of P but could correlate. If he attends, he is more likely to make a statement, but he could also make a statement without attending. Thus, I would estimate a moderate probability here as well.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This probability is contingent upon both events happening. The estimated probability will be lower than either P or Q alone and will need to be calculated based on their individual probabilities.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This probability will be higher than both P and Q individually, as it accounts for either event occurring. I will use the formula for the union of two probabilities to estimate this value.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not_P occurs)**: This situation is interesting because it requires that Musk makes a statement without attending. I will need to estimate this probability carefully, as it depends on the independence of Q and not_P.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given that P occurs)**: This conditional probability will depend on the relationship between P and Q. If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases, so I will need to estimate this accordingly.

Overall, I will ensure that all the probabilities respect the consistency rules laid out, particularly focusing on the relationships between P, not_P, and Q, as well as their combinations. This will help maintain a coherent set of estimates.

question.title: Will Nikki Haley be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Nikki Haley is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

For the questions regarding Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 event, I will analyze the probabilities based on various factors that could influence his attendance and public statements about Bitcoin. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability will be influenced by Musk's historical engagement with Bitcoin and cryptocurrency events, as well as his current public interests and commitments. Given his significant role in the crypto space, I estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend, say around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is closely related to P and should have a similar probability, so I would also estimate this around 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability is influenced by whether he attends the event. If he attends, the likelihood of him making a statement increases, but not necessarily guarantees it. I estimate this at 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both events occur: Musk shows up and makes a statement?)**: This is a joint probability and should be less than or equal to both individual probabilities. I estimate this at 0.45.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either event occur?)**: This probability should be greater than or equal to the individual probabilities and typically calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. I estimate this at 0.80.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both occur: Musk makes a statement and does not show up?)**: This is a more complex scenario. If he makes a statement, it usually implies he is present, making this probability low, perhaps around 0.05.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that Musk shows up, will he make a statement?)**: This conditional probability should be high if he shows up, as I would expect him to make a statement if he is present. I estimate this at about 0.85.

Considering the relationships between these probabilities, I will ensure that they adhere to the consistency rules provided. For example, not_P must equal 1 - P, and the joint probabilities must respect the bounds defined by the individual probabilities. I will check all of this when I finalize the estimates.

question.title: Will Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and Nikki Haley not be the nominee?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Nikki Haley is not selected as the nominee. If both conditions are met, the question resolves as **Yes**; otherwise, it resolves as **No**.

This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is simply the complement of P, which would be 1 - P. Thus, not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially the same as P, so I would assign it the same probability of 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This could be influenced by his attendance but also by other factors like current events or his strategy around Bitcoin. I might estimate this at 0.60 based on the likelihood of him discussing Bitcoin in public.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This probability should be lower than both P and Q, as both events need to happen simultaneously. A reasonable estimate might be around 0.40, reflecting the intersection of both events.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This probability should be higher than either individual probability. Using the formula for the union of two events, I might estimate this at 0.75, considering the likelihood of at least one occurring.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will Q occur while not P occurs?)**: This situation can occur if Musk makes a statement but does not attend. I might estimate this at 0.15 based on the likelihood of him discussing Bitcoin without attending.

8. **Q_given_P (Given P, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability would likely be higher than Q alone if he attends, so I might estimate this at 0.75, indicating a strong correlation between attendance and making a statement.

Overall, I will ensure that all estimates obey the consistency rules, particularly focusing on the relationships between P and not_P, as well as the conjunctions and disjunctions of P and Q. question.title: Will either Nikki Haley or Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Nikki Haley or Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will Larry Elder be the Republican nominee and Glenn Youngkin not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Glenn Youngkin is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will either Glenn Youngkin or Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Glenn Youngkin or Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are evaluating a series of questions regarding Elon Musk's potential involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The key questions include whether he will show up (P), whether he will not show up (not_P), whether he will make a public statement about Bitcoin (Q), and various combinations of these events.

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is likely influenced by Musk's prior engagements and interest in Bitcoin. Given his past involvement in cryptocurrency discussions, I would estimate a moderate to high probability for P, say around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If P is estimated at 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35, as they must sum to 1.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is similar to P, as it asks about his attendance. I would keep this estimate similar to P, around 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question could be independent of P; he might make a statement even if he doesn't show up. However, there might be a correlation based on his engagement at the conference. I would estimate Q at around 0.50.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This requires both P and Q to be true. I would estimate this at 0.40, taking into account the probability of both events happening together, which is less than the individual probabilities of each.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This question asks if at least one of P or Q will happen. Using the formula for the union of two probabilities, I would estimate this at around 0.75.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q and not_P occur?)**: This scenario is a bit more complex, as it requires Q to be true while P is false. I would estimate this at around 0.25, given that Q can still happen without P.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P is true, will Q be true?)**: This conditional probability is likely higher than Q alone, as if Musk shows up, he may also make a statement. I would estimate this at around 0.70.

Overall, the estimates need to adhere to the consistency rules provided, ensuring that they align mathematically. The relationships between P and Q, and their combinations, will guide adjustments to ensure all consistency checks pass.

Q_and_not_P: 0.25,

question.title: Will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and Donald Trump Jr. not be the nominee?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Donald Trump Jr. is not selected as the nominee. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently considered; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In evaluating the probability estimates for the various questions related to Elon Musk's potential involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I considered several factors:

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is a binary event that depends on Musk's availability and interest in attending the conference. Given his previous engagements with Bitcoin and cryptocurrency, I estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is simply the complement of P. If I estimate P at a certain value, not_P will be 1 minus that value.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is essentially a rephrasing of P, so I expect it to have the same probability estimate as P.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is somewhat independent of P, as he could make a statement without attending. However, his attendance could increase the likelihood of him making a statement. I estimate a moderate probability for this event as well.

question.title: Will either Donald Trump Jr. or Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Donald Trump Jr. or Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:
Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Otherwise, resolves NO.

For the event regarding Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, I will assess the probabilities based on various factors such as his historical engagement with Bitcoin, his public persona, and the significance of the event. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)** - Given Musk's previous involvement in Bitcoin discussions and events, I estimate a moderately high probability that he will show up, likely around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)** - This is the complement of P and will be estimated at 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)** - This is very similar to P and should be equal to it, so I will also estimate this at 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)** - Given that he often makes statements about Bitcoin around significant events, I will estimate this at 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)** - This requires both events to happen simultaneously. Assuming some correlation, I estimate this at 0.45.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)** - This can be calculated using the formula for the union of two events: P + Q - P_and_Q. Thus, I estimate it at 0.65 + 0.70 - 0.45 = 0.90.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P?)** - This is trickier as it involves Q happening while P does not. I estimate this at 0.20, considering that he might still make a statement even if he doesn't show up.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)** - If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases. I estimate this at 0.85.

**Independence and Relationships:** 
- P and Q are not independent; if Musk shows up, it increases the likelihood of him making a statement. 
- The relationship between P_and_Q and P_or_Q is governed by the addition of probabilities and intersections, which is reflected in the calculations above.

question.title: Will Joe Biden remain President through the end of July 2024 and not die before Saturday, July 26th, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Joe Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (Eastern Time). This means he does not resign, die, or otherwise cease to be President before then. A temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment, making his VP the Acting President, does not cause a NO resolution as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution. (b) There is no official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. If both conditions are satisfied, the question resolves YES. If either or both conditions are not satisfied, the question resolves NO.

5. **P_and_Q (Both occur)**: The joint probability of both showing up and making a statement would be lower than either event occurring independently, so I would estimate this probability accordingly.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Public statement but does not show up)**: This scenario is plausible, especially if he makes a statement remotely. I would assign a moderate probability here.

8. **Q_given_P (Statement given attendance)**: If he shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases significantly, so this probability should be high.

By carefully considering the relationships between these events and applying the consistency rules, I can ensure that the probabilities align correctly.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden dies before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, or (b) Joe Biden does not remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. (b) Joe Biden ceases to be the US President before the end of July 2024 (ET) due to resignation, death, or any other reason. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect the YES resolution for part (b). Otherwise, the question resolves NO.

question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will Nikki Haley be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and not Donald Trump Jr.?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Nikki Haley is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Donald Trump Jr. is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other scenarios will resolve as **No**.

This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future. In this scenario, we are assessing the probabilities related to Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: This is a binary event where the prediction is based on factors such as Elon Musk's previous engagements, his public interest in Bitcoin, and the prominence of the event. Given Musk's high profile and the significance of the conference, I might estimate this probability around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is simply the complement of P, so it would be 1 - P, which would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Chance of attendance)**: This is similar to P, as it also concerns his attendance. Thus, I would keep this value aligned with P, estimating it at 0.60.

4. **Q (Public statement about Bitcoin)**: This event is independent of P but could be influenced by it. Given Musk's history of discussing Bitcoin publicly, I might estimate this at 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Both occur)**: The likelihood of both events happening is generally the product of their individual probabilities, assuming independence. Thus, I would estimate this around P * Q = 0.60 * 0.70 = 0.42.

6. **P_or_Q (Either occurs)**: This combines the probabilities of P and Q, so I would calculate it as P + Q - P_and_Q = 0.60 + 0.70 - 0.42 = 0.88.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Public statement without attendance)**: This event requires Q to occur while not P happens. Given that Musk can still make a statement without attending, I might estimate this at a lower probability, perhaps around 0.30.

8. **Q_given_P (Statement given attendance)**: This conditional probability would likely be high, as if Musk shows up, he is likely to make a statement. I would estimate this at around 0.80.

Overall, I will ensure that the values I assign adhere to the consistency rules, specifically checking the relationships between P, Q, and their combinations.

question.title: Will either Donald Trump Jr. or Nikki Haley be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Donald Trump Jr. or Nikki Haley is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.body:

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: The probability of this event is influenced by Musk's past behavior at similar events, his current level of engagement with the Bitcoin community, and any announcements leading up to the conference. Given Musk's significant influence in the crypto space, I would estimate this probability to be moderately high, perhaps around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is simply the complement of P. If I estimate P at 0.60, then not_P would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend)**: This is essentially the same as P, so I would assign it the same probability, 0.60.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin)**: The likelihood of Musk making a public statement about Bitcoin could be influenced by his current sentiments towards Bitcoin, any recent developments in the cryptocurrency market, and his media presence. I would estimate this probability to be around 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: The probability of both events happening is likely lower than either event happening individually, as they are not fully dependent. I would estimate this at around 0.45.

6. **P_or_Q (At least one of P or Q occurs)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q alone. I would estimate it to be around 0.85, reflecting the likelihood that at least one of these events will occur.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while P does not)**: This is a more complex case. For this event to be true, Musk would need to make a public statement without showing up. Given the nature of the events, I would estimate this probability to be lower, perhaps around 0.25.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This is a conditional probability. If Musk shows up, he might be more likely to make a statement. I would estimate this probability at around 0.80.

In summary, I will provide the estimates based on the reasoning above, ensuring they adhere to the consistency rules.

question.title: Will either Vivek Ramaswamy or Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Vivek Ramaswamy or Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

For the question of whether Elon Musk will show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (P), I would assess this based on his past attendance at similar events, his current engagement with the Bitcoin community, and any announcements related to the event. P_and_Q would be the joint occurrence of both P and Q, so I would consider the intersection of the probabilities of these two events happening together, which would naturally be lower than either happening individually.

P_or_Q would encompass either event happening, so I would expect this value to be higher than both P and Q individually.

For Q_and_not_P, this would require that he makes a public statement but does not show up, which might be less likely given that his attendance could lead to a public statement.

Finally, Q_given_P would require that if he does show up, there’s a certain probability he will make a statement about Bitcoin. This would likely be higher than the unconditional probability of Q since his presence at the event may increase the likelihood of him making a statement.

In terms of independence, P and Q may not be completely independent since his attendance (P) could influence whether he makes a statement (Q). Therefore, I would expect some correlation between these probabilities.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

In this scenario, we are evaluating the likelihood of various outcomes related to Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This prediction hinges on Musk's public persona and previous attendance at high-profile events. Given his significant interest in cryptocurrency, I estimate a moderate probability of him attending, say 0.60.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is the complement of P, so it would be 1 - P, which would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is essentially the same as P, so it would also be 0.60.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin)**: Given Musk's history of discussing Bitcoin publicly, I would estimate this probability at 0.75.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This requires both events to happen. Assuming some correlation, I might estimate this at 0.45, reflecting a reasonable chance that if he attends, he will also make a statement.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This is more likely than either event alone, so I would estimate it at 0.80.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not P)**: This would require Musk to make a statement without showing up, which is less likely, so I estimate this at 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given that P occurs)**: If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases. I estimate this at 0.90.

The relationships between these probabilities are important. For instance, P and not_P are complements, and para_P should equal P. The events Q and P are likely correlated, as attendance may lead to public statements. I will ensure that all estimates adhere to the consistency rules outlined.

not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.60,
Q: 0.75,
P_and_Q: 0.45,
P_or_Q: 0.80,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.90

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model, and (b) Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
(a) Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model: Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise. Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

(b) Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President: Resolves YES if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign does not make a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a Yes resolution, the absence of such a statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No. Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus. Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

In this scenario, we are evaluating the probabilities surrounding Elon Musk's potential participation at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The questions revolve around his attendance, public statements about Bitcoin, and the relationships between these events.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This event is likely to occur given Musk's history of involvement in cryptocurrency discussions and events. However, since there are factors like scheduling conflicts or personal decisions that could affect his attendance, I estimate a probability of around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is the complement of P. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35, reflecting the chance that he might not attend.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend)**: This is similar to P and should have the same probability estimate, as it is essentially asking the same question in a different format. Thus, I estimate it at 0.65.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin)**: This event could occur regardless of his attendance. Given his active engagement with Bitcoin, I estimate this probability at 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: For this to happen, Musk must show up and make a statement. I estimate this probability at 0.45, considering that both events are somewhat correlated but not entirely dependent.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This probability should be higher than both individual probabilities. I estimate it at 0.80, as there is a good chance that at least one of these events will happen.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not_P occurs)**: This scenario is plausible if Musk makes a statement without attending. I estimate this probability at 0.25, reflecting the possibility of him commenting on Bitcoin without being present at the event.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases. I estimate this at 0.85, indicating a strong correlation between his attendance and making a statement.

The independence of P and Q is essential in this evaluation. While they are related, they are not mutually exclusive, allowing for a combination of probabilities. I will ensure that my estimates adhere to the consistency rules outlined.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, or (b) Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body: (a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive. If such a statement is not made by the deadline, this resolves as No. (b) Will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model? This resolves as Yes if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is greater than 46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves No otherwise.

In this scenario, we are considering the likelihood of Elon Musk's attendance and statements at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is contingent upon Elon Musk being a guest on the official stage, which is a highly publicized event. Given Musk's previous engagements and interest in Bitcoin, I estimate a moderate probability of him attending, say around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complementary event to P, so its probability can be derived from the estimate of P. If P is 0.60, then not_P would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is essentially asking the same as P, so I would estimate this to be the same probability as P, which is 0.60.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given Musk's history of engaging with Bitcoin, I would assign this a probability of around 0.70, as he often comments on Bitcoin-related events.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: For both to occur, we need both probabilities. Assuming independence for simplicity, this would be P * Q = 0.60 * 0.70 = 0.42.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This can be calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. Thus, it would be 0.60 + 0.70 - 0.42 = 0.88.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P occur?)**: This would require that Musk makes a statement without attending the conference. Assuming some independence, this probability can be estimated as Q * not_P = 0.70 * 0.40 = 0.28.

8. **Q_given_P (Given P, will Q occur?)**: If we know Musk is attending, the likelihood of him making a statement about Bitcoin might increase. I might estimate this at around 0.85, reflecting that his presence at the conference likely correlates with him making a statement about Bitcoin.

Overall, these probabilities reflect a careful consideration of the events' interdependencies and the context surrounding Elon Musk's engagement with Bitcoin.

question.title: Will the USA both top the Olympic Medal Table and win as many or more Silver than Gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if both of the following occur:
(a) The United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:
1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

(b) The United States Olympic Team wins as many or more Silver medals than Gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

The question will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027.

question.title: Will either of the following occur at the Paris 2024 Olympics: (a) The USA wins more Gold than Silver medals (b) The USA tops the Olympic Medal Table?
question.body:
This question resolves YES if either of the following conditions are met:
(a) The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.
(b) The United States Olympic Team is the unique highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics, based on the medal table which orders countries by the number of Gold medals, then Silver medals, then Bronze medals. This question resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It resolves NO if neither condition is met.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This probability will depend on Musk's schedule, his interest in Bitcoin, and his history with such events. Given his previous involvement and public interest in cryptocurrency, I estimate a moderate to high probability for this event.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is high, not_P will be low, and vice versa. 

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend)**: This is similar to P, so I would expect it to have a similar probability. 

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin during the conference)**: This event is also likely, as Musk frequently discusses Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies. However, it is independent of his attendance. 

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This probability should be lower than either P or Q alone because it requires both events to happen simultaneously. 

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q alone since it allows for either event to happen. 

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not_P occurs)**: This event is plausible since Musk could make a statement without attending. This will depend on how often he engages with the public about Bitcoin without being physically present.

8. **Q_given_P (If P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability will likely be high because if Musk attends, he may be inclined to make a statement about Bitcoin. 

In summary, I will assign probabilities based on these considerations and ensure they adhere to the consistency rules provided.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Donald Trump will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Donald Trump will not be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met:

1. Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

2. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has not been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. There must be no official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports confirming such a removal or block. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has not been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves positively.

The question will resolve as **No** if either or both of these conditions are not met.

In forecasting the probabilities related to Elon Musk's participation and statements during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I will consider the relationships and dependencies between the events. 

**P:** This represents the probability that Elon Musk will show up at the conference. Given his public persona and previous engagements with Bitcoin, I estimate a reasonably high probability for this event. 

**not_P:** This is the complementary event to P, indicating that he does not show up. If P is high, not_P will naturally be lower. 

**para_P:** This probability aligns closely with P, as it refers to the same event but is phrased differently. I expect it to be similar to P. 

**Q:** This event concerns Musk making a public statement about Bitcoin during the conference. Given his history of discussing Bitcoin, I estimate this probability to be moderate. 

**P_and_Q:** This is the probability that both P and Q occur. Since these events are not entirely independent, I expect this probability to be lower than either P or Q alone but still significant if both events are likely. 

**P_or_Q:** This probability captures the likelihood that at least one of the events (P or Q) occurs. It should be higher than both individual probabilities but cannot exceed 1. 

**Q_and_not_P:** This event occurs if Musk makes a statement about Bitcoin but does not show up. This is plausible, as he could make statements remotely, so I expect this to be a moderate probability. 

**Q_given_P:** This conditional probability reflects the likelihood of Q occurring given that P occurs. If Musk shows up, the chance of him making a statement is likely higher, thus this probability should be relatively high. 

Overall, the estimates will need to respect the consistency rules, ensuring that the probabilities align with the logical relationships between these events.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024? (b) Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if either of the following conditions is met:

(a) As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as "No". This question may consider new candidates added in the future. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P, and thus I would set this at 0.40, as it logically follows that if there's a 60% chance he will show up, there's a 40% chance he will not.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially the same question as P, and thus I will set this equal to P, at 0.60.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given his past engagement with Bitcoin, I estimate a probability of 0.70 for him making a public statement during the conference, which is a higher likelihood than him showing up.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: The probability of both events happening can be calculated using the formula for the intersection of two independent events. Given the estimates for P and Q, I would set this at 0.42, reflecting the likelihood of both occurring together.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This can be calculated using the formula for the union of two events. Given the probabilities for P and Q, I would estimate this at 0.88, indicating a high likelihood that at least one of the two events will occur.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P occur?)**: This scenario is less likely, as it requires Musk to make a statement without showing up. I would estimate this at 0.15, reflecting the lower likelihood of this combination.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: If Musk shows up, the likelihood that he will make a statement increases. I would estimate this conditional probability at 0.80, reflecting the higher chance of him discussing Bitcoin if he is present.

Overall, I will ensure that all estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided, particularly ensuring that the relationships between these probabilities are logically sound and mathematically consistent.

question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will Nikki Haley be the Republican nominee and Mike Pence not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following occur: (a) Nikki Haley is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (b) Mike Pence is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are predicting various events related to Elon Musk's potential involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The key questions revolve around whether he will show up at the event (P), whether he will not show up (not_P), whether he will make a public statement about Bitcoin (Q), and the relationships between these events.

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability is based on factors such as Musk's previous attendance at similar events, his interest in Bitcoin, and any announcements or indications he has made regarding the conference. Given his strong ties to the cryptocurrency community, I estimate this probability to be moderately high.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If P is high, then not_P must be low. I estimate this to be lower than not_P, reflecting the belief that he is likely to attend.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially the same as P, so I expect it to have similar values, as they refer to the same event.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability is influenced by Musk's history of discussing Bitcoin publicly and the likelihood of him making a statement regardless of his attendance. This could be moderately high, given his prominence in the crypto community.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This probability is the intersection of P and Q. If both events are likely, then this probability should be higher than either P or Q alone, but less than the sum of both due to potential overlap.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This is a union of the two events. The probability should be higher than either individual event but must still respect the limits of probability (i.e., cannot exceed 1).

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P occur?)**: This probability reflects the scenario where Musk makes a statement but does not attend. Given the nature of the events, this could be a plausible scenario but should be lower than Q alone.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability reflects the likelihood of Q happening if P has happened. If Musk attends, it increases the chances that he will also make a statement.

Overall, the probabilities are interlinked, and I will ensure that they adhere to the consistency rules provided. Each prediction must respect the relationships defined by the consistency rules, ensuring that they do not contradict one another.

question.title: Will either Mike Pence or Nikki Haley be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Mike Pence or Nikki Haley is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not P)**: This scenario considers the possibility of Musk making a statement without attending. The probability here should reflect the independence of the two events.

8. **Q_given_P (Q given P)**: This conditional probability assesses how likely Q is if P occurs. If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement about Bitcoin should increase significantly.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 (b) Chris Christie is not the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question resolves **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met:

(a) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. This includes any of the following individuals being the nominee:
 - Donald Trump
 - Donald Trump Jr.
 - Eric Trump
 - Ivanka Trump
 - Tiffany Trump
 - Melania Trump
 - Barron Trump

(b) Chris Christie is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It does not matter who else is selected as the nominee, as long as it is not Chris Christie. This determination is based on the selection by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not on the eventual candidate on the day of the election.

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: I would estimate a moderate to high probability for this event, as Elon Musk is known to engage with the cryptocurrency community, particularly Bitcoin. However, attendance at a specific event can be contingent upon many factors, including scheduling conflicts or personal preferences. Thus, I might set this probability around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. Given that I estimate P at 0.65, I would set not_P at 0.35. This captures the possibility that he might not attend.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is essentially synonymous with P, so I would assign it the same probability of 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Considering his active engagement with Bitcoin, there is a reasonable chance that he might make a statement, even if he does not attend the event. I would estimate this probability at 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: The probability of both events occurring is likely lower than the individual probabilities of P and Q due to their potential independence. A reasonable estimate might be around 0.45, reflecting that there is a significant chance of both happening together.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This is where the probabilities can add up, potentially exceeding 1 when considering overlaps. I would calculate this using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q, leading to an estimate of around 0.90.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P occur?)**: This scenario describes a situation where he makes a statement without showing up. I would estimate this at around 0.15, as it is plausible but less likely than the combined attendance and statement.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q also occur?)**: If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases significantly. I would estimate this at around 0.85, reflecting a strong correlation between attendance and making a statement.

In summary, I expect the probabilities to reflect a reasonable assessment of Elon Musk's engagement with Bitcoin and the likelihood of his actions at the upcoming conference. Each of these probabilities should adhere to the consistency rules, particularly regarding complements and intersections.

question.title: Will either Chris Christie or a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Chris Christie or any member of the Trump family is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. For Chris Christie, the resolution is based on his selection by the delegates of the Republican National Convention. For the Trump family, this includes any of the following individuals being selected: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump.

In this scenario, we are evaluating several questions regarding Elon Musk's potential participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. The key events to consider are whether he will show up (P), whether he will not show up (not_P), whether he will make a public statement about Bitcoin (Q), and the combinations of these events.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: The likelihood of Elon Musk showing up at the conference depends on various factors, including his public interest in Bitcoin and previous attendance at similar events. Given his history, I estimate a moderate to high probability of him attending, say around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: The probability of him not showing up is the complement of him showing up. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Chance of attending)**: This is essentially the same as P, so it would also be around 0.65.

4. **Q (Public statement about Bitcoin)**: Elon Musk has been vocal about Bitcoin in the past. Given the context of the conference, I would estimate the probability of him making a statement about Bitcoin to be around 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Both occur)**: This probability would be less than both P and Q, as it requires both events to occur. I might estimate this to be around 0.45.

6. **P_or_Q (Either occurs)**: This should be calculated based on the probabilities of P and Q, ensuring it does not exceed 1. A rough estimate would be around 0.90, as it's likely one of the two will happen.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Statement without attendance)**: This scenario is plausible if he makes a statement but does not attend. I would estimate this to be around 0.25.

8. **Q_given_P (Statement given attendance)**: If he attends, the likelihood of him making a statement would be higher than if he did not attend. I might estimate this at around 0.80, reflecting that his presence would likely lead to a statement.

Overall, these predictions must adhere to the consistency rules provided. The relationships between P, not_P, Q, and their combinations should be carefully managed to ensure they remain within logical bounds. Specifically, the probabilities for not_P must be complementary to P, and the probabilities for P_and_Q must respect the constraints imposed by the individual probabilities of P and Q.

question.title: Will Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In predicting the probabilities for the events surrounding Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I consider the following factors:

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This prediction is likely influenced by Musk's past involvement in similar events and his general interest in Bitcoin. Given his prominence in the cryptocurrency space, I might estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If I estimate a certain probability for P, then not_P would be 1 minus that probability. This relationship ensures that both probabilities are consistent.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially a rephrasing of P, so it should have the same probability as P.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is somewhat independent of P, as Musk could make a statement without attending. However, his attendance may increase the likelihood of him making a statement, which could influence the probability estimate.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This is a joint event where both P and Q must happen. The probability of this event is generally less than or equal to the individual probabilities of P and Q, and I need to ensure that it reflects the relationship between these two events accurately.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This is the union of P and Q. The probability should reflect that at least one of the two events happens, and it can be calculated using the individual probabilities of P and Q along with their joint probability (P_and_Q).

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will Q occur while not P occurs?)**: This scenario is interesting because it allows for Q to happen independently of P. The probability should be low if I believe that Musk's attendance is somewhat necessary for him to make a statement.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability should reflect how likely Q is if I know P has happened. Given that Musk's attendance may increase the likelihood of him making a statement, I would expect this probability to be higher than Q alone.

In summary, I will ensure that all these probabilities are consistent with each other, adhering to the logical relationships defined by the consistency rules. I will check the relationships between these events, especially how P and Q interact, to maintain the integrity of the estimates.

question.title: Will Ron DeSantis be the Republican nominee and Larry Elder not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Ron DeSantis is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (b) Larry Elder is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Larry Elder or Ron DeSantis is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.
