1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This probability will depend on Musk's schedule, interest in Bitcoin, and historical attendance at similar events. Given his previous engagement with the Bitcoin community, I might estimate this probability to be moderately high.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is the complement of P. If P is estimated to be moderately high, then not_P will be lower, reflecting the uncertainty surrounding his attendance.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend)**: This is essentially a rephrased version of P, so it is expected to have the same probability as P.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin)**: This could occur independently of his attendance. Given Musk's history of discussing Bitcoin publicly, I might estimate this probability to be moderate as well.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given that P occurs)**: This conditional probability will depend on how likely Musk is to make a statement if he is present at the conference. If he is there, the likelihood of him speaking could be higher.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are evaluating multiple events related to Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is a direct binary question regarding Musk's attendance. Given his previous involvement with Bitcoin and the prominence of the event, I estimate a moderate to high probability of him attending, say around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P, so it would be 1 - P. If P is estimated at 0.65, not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially the same as P, so it will also be around 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is somewhat independent of P but could be correlated. Given Musk's history with Bitcoin, I would estimate this at 0.60.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both occur: Musk shows up and makes a statement?)**: The probability of both events occurring would typically be less than or equal to the individual probabilities. Assuming some positive correlation, I might estimate this at around 0.40.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either occur: Musk shows up or makes a statement?)**: This should be greater than or equal to the maximum of P and Q and less than or equal to the sum of both probabilities minus their intersection (P_and_Q). I would estimate this at about 0.75.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both occur: Musk makes a statement and does not show up?)**: This is a more complex relationship as it involves independent probabilities. I would estimate this at a lower probability, around 0.15, as it requires him to make a statement without being present.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up, will he make a statement?)**: This conditional probability would be higher than Q alone since his presence at the conference would likely increase the chance of him making a statement. I would estimate this at around 0.80.

Overall, I believe these events are interconnected, with P and Q having a positive correlation due to Musk's interest in Bitcoin. However, they also have independent probabilities, which need to be respected in the consistency checks.

question.title: Will Francis Suarez be the Republican nominee and Donald Trump not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Francis Suarez is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (b) Donald Trump is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, I will evaluate the probabilities related to Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 event. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability will depend on various factors, such as his prior commitments, interest in Bitcoin, and the significance of the event. I estimate a moderate probability that he will attend, given his previous involvement in cryptocurrency discussions.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If I estimate a 70% chance for P, then not_P would be 30%. 

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially the same as P, so I would assign it the same probability.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given his history of making statements about Bitcoin, I would assign a relatively high probability to this question, as he might comment on the cryptocurrency regardless of whether he is physically present.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both occur: Musk shows up and makes a statement?)**: This probability will be lower than either P or Q alone, as it requires both conditions to be true. I would estimate it based on the intersection of the two probabilities.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either occur: Musk shows up or makes a statement?)**: This probability will be higher than either P or Q alone, as it covers both possibilities. 

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will Musk make a statement but not show up?)**: This is a specific scenario that could happen if he makes a statement remotely or through other means. I would assign a moderate probability to this.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up, will he make a statement?)**: This conditional probability should be high, as his attendance would likely lead to him making comments about Bitcoin.

These probabilities will need to adhere to the consistency rules, ensuring that relationships between them are mathematically valid. For example, the sum of P and not_P must equal 1, and the probabilities of P_and_Q and P_or_Q must also adhere to their respective rules.

question.title: Will either Donald Trump or Francis Suarez be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Donald Trump or Francis Suarez is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In evaluating the probability estimates for the various questions regarding Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, I considered several factors:

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: This probability is influenced by Musk's past involvement in Bitcoin discussions and conferences, as well as the significance of the event. Given his prominence in the cryptocurrency space, I estimate this probability to be moderately high.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is estimated to be high, not_P will be correspondingly lower.

3. **para_P (Chance of Musk attending)**: Since para_P is essentially the same event as P, I expect this to have a similar probability, reflecting the likelihood of Musk's attendance as a speaker.

4. **Q (Public statement about Bitcoin)**: Musk has a history of making public statements about Bitcoin and cryptocurrency, which could lead to a moderate probability estimate for this event.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occurring)**: This probability is dependent on both P and Q being true simultaneously. I estimate it to be lower than either P or Q individually due to the intersection nature of this event.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurring)**: This probability should be higher than both individual probabilities, as it encompasses either scenario happening.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurring while not P)**: This scenario is interesting because it suggests that Musk could make a statement without attending. Given his history, this is plausible but not guaranteed, so I estimate it to be lower than Q alone.
